prompt:
The following is a first-order logic (FOL) problem.
The problem is to determine whether the conclusion follows from the premises.
The premises are given in the form of a set of first-order logic sentences.
The conclusion is given in the form of a single first-order logic sentence.
The task is to translate each of the premises and conclusions into FOL expressions so that the expressions can be evaluated by a theorem solver like Prover9 to determine whether the conclusion follows from the premises.
There should be a reasoning step in the middle starting with REASONING:.. 
The output should follow format TEXT: 
REASONING: 
FOL: 
TEXT: 
REASONING: 
FOL:...Expressions should adhere to the format of the Python NLTK package logic module.Remember to never the FOL predicates too long or overlapping meanings with other predicates.
 Also you must not have empty predicates like Conductor().Symbols like <, >, =, <-> are not allowed.


<PREMISES>
All dispensable things are environment-friendly.
All woodware is dispensable.
All paper is woodware.
No good things are bad.
All environment-friendly things are good.
A worksheet is either paper or is environment-friendly.
</PREMISES>
<CONCLUSION>
A worksheet is not dispensable.
</CONCLUSION>
<EVALUATE>
TEXT: All dispensable things are environment-friendly. 
REASONING: We universally quantify over every entity, asserting that being dispensable implies being environment-friendly.
FOL: all x. (Dispensable(x) -> EnvironmentFriendly(x))
TEXT: All woodware is dispensable.
REASONING: Every instance of woodware falls under the dispensable category.
FOL: all x. (Woodware(x) -> Dispensable(x))
TEXT: All paper is woodware. 
REASONING: Paper is a subset of woodware, so paper implies woodware.
FOL: all x. (Paper(x) -> Woodware(x))
TEXT: No good things are bad. 
REASONING: For every x, if x is good then x cannot be bad.
FOL: all x. (Good(x) -> -Bad(x))
TEXT: All environment-friendly things are good.
REASONING: Environment-friendly implies good.
FOL: all x. (EnvironmentFriendly(x) -> Good(x))
TEXT: A worksheet is either paper or is environment-friendly.
REASONING: Worksheet must be in exactly one of those two categories.
FOL: ((Paper(Worksheet) & -EnvironmentFriendly(Worksheet)) | (-Paper(Worksheet) & EnvironmentFriendly(Worksheet)))
TEXT: A worksheet is not dispensable.
REASONING: We assert the negation of dispensability for the specific constant Worksheet.
FOL: -Dispensable(Worksheet)
</EVALUATE>

<PREMISES>
A La Liga soccer team ranks higher than another if it receives more points.
If two La Liga soccer teams recieve the same points, the team which recieves more points from the games between the two teams ranks higher.
Real Madrid and Barcelona are both La Liga soccer teams.
In La Liga 2021-2022, Real Madrid recieves 86 points and Barcelon recieves 73 points.
In La Liga 2021-2022, Real Madrid and Barcelona both recieve 3 points from the games between them.
</PREMISES>
<CONCLUSION>
In La Liga 2021-2022, Real Madrid ranks higher than Barcelona.
</CONCLUSION>
<EVALUATE>
TEXT: A La Liga soccer team ranks higher than another if it receives more points.
REASONING: If both are in La Liga and x has strictly more total points than y, then x outranks y.
FOL: all x. all y. (LaLiga(x) & LaLiga(y) & MorePoints(x, y) -> HigherRank(x, y))
TEXT: If two La Liga soccer teams recieve the same points, the team which recieves more points from the games between the two teams ranks higher.
REASONING: If neither has more overall points but x outscored y in their head-to-head matches, then x outranks y.
FOL: all x. all y. (LaLiga(x) & LaLiga(y) & -MorePoints(x, y) & -MorePoints(y, x) & MorePointsInGameBetween(x, y) -> HigherRank(x, y))
TEXT: Real Madrid and Barcelona are both La Liga soccer teams.
REASONING: Membership in La Liga is asserted for both Real Madrid and Barcelona.
FOL: LaLiga(RealMadrid) & LaLiga(Barcelona)
TEXT: In La Liga 2021-2022, Real Madrid recieves 86 points and Barcelon recieves 73 points.
REASONING: We record that Real Madrid has more total points.
FOL: MorePoints(RealMadrid, Barcelona)
TEXT: In La Liga 2021-2022, Real Madrid and Barcelona both recieve 3 points from the games between them.
REASONING: Neither team outscored the other in their direct matches.
FOL: -MorePointsInGameBetween(RealMadrid, Barcelona) & -MorePointsInGameBetween(Barcelona, RealMadrid)
TEXT: In La Liga 2021-2022, Real Madrid ranks higher than Barcelona.
REASONING: We test whether the ranking relation holds under these facts.
FOL: HigherRank(RealMadrid, Barcelona)
</EVALUATE>

<PREMISES>
All athletes are good at sports.
All Olympic gold medal winners are good athletes.
No scientists are good at sports.
All Nobel laureates are scientists.
Amy is good at sports or Amy is an Olympic gold medal winner.
If Amy is not a Nobel laureate, then Amy is not an Olympic gold medal winner.
</PREMISES>
<CONCLUSION>
If Amy is not an Olympic gold medal winner, then Amy is a Nobel laureate.
</CONCLUSION>
<EVALUATE>
TEXT: All athletes are good at sports.
REASONING: Every athlete excels at sports, so we quantify universally over Athlete(x) implying GoodAtSports(x).
FOL: all x. (Athlete(x) -> GoodAtSports(x))
TEXT: All Olympic gold medal winners are good athletes.
REASONING: Gold-medal winners are a subclass of athletes, so OlympicGoldMedalWinner(x) → Athlete(x).
FOL: all x. (OlympicGoldMedalWinner(x) -> Athlete(x))
TEXT: No scientists are good at sports.
REASONING: Scientists cannot be good at sports, eliminating overlap between those classes.
FOL: all x. (Scientist(x) -> -GoodAtSports(x))
TEXT: All Nobel laureates are scientists.
REASONING: Nobel laureates inherit scientist status, capturing the relationship to scientists.
FOL: all x. (NobelLaureate(x) -> Scientist(x))
TEXT: Amy is good at sports or Amy is an Olympic gold medal winner.
REASONING: Amy must satisfy at least one: being good at sports or being a gold-medal winner.
FOL: GoodAtSports(Amy) | OlympicGoldMedalWinner(Amy)
TEXT: If Amy is not a Nobel laureate, then Amy is not an Olympic gold medal winner.
REASONING: Non-laureates cannot be gold-medal winners, linking laureate status to medal wins.
FOL: -NobelLaureate(Amy) -> -OlympicGoldMedalWinner(Amy)
TEXT: If Amy is not an Olympic gold medal winner, then Amy is a Nobel laureate.
REASONING: We check whether the inverted implication ‘not gold medal → laureate’ follows.
FOL: -OlympicGoldMedalWinner(Amy) -> NobelLaureate(Amy)
</EVALUATE>

<PREMISES>
All people who are respected by others are people who contribute to the country.
If a person is respected by others, then he/she contributes to the country.
All people available to have a visit without any fees are those respected by others.
All Customers who once served in the army are available to have a visit without any fees.
All people who once were sentenced for thief stayed in prison for some time.
All people who once stayed in prison for some time have a bad record in the local state.
James was either once sentenced for thief or stayed in prison for some time.
James is either with a bad record in the local state or respected by others.
</PREMISES>
<CONCLUSION>
James contributes to the country.
</CONCLUSION>
<EVALUATE>
TEXT: All people who are respected by others are people who contribute to the country. 
REASONING: Respect implies contribution, so anyone respected by others contributes to the country.
FOL: all x. (Respected(x) -> ContributeToCountry(x))
TEXT: If a person is respected by others, then he/she contributes to the country. 
REASONING: We restate that respect carries the same implication to reinforce it.
FOL: all x. (Respected(x) -> ContributeToCountry(x))
TEXT: All people available to have a visit without any fees are those respected by others. 
REASONING: Fee-free visitors must be respected, creating a chain from visit status to respect.
FOL: all x. (HaveVisitWithoutAnyFees(x) -> Respected(x))
TEXT: All Customers who once served in the army are available to have a visit without any fees. 
REASONING: Veterans (Army service) are granted fee-free access, linking army(x) → HaveVisitWithoutAnyFees(x).
FOL: all x. (Army(x) -> HaveVisitWithoutAnyFees(x))
TEXT: All people who once were sentenced for thief stayed in prison for some time. 
REASONING: Thieves go to prison, capturing wrongdoing leading to punishment.
FOL: all x. (Thief(x) -> Prison(x))
TEXT: All people who once stayed in prison for some time have a bad record in the local state. 
REASONING: Prison time entails a bad record, chaining Prison(x) → BadRecord(x).
FOL: all x. (Prison(x) -> BadRecord(x))
TEXT: James was either once sentenced for thief or stayed in prison for some time. 
REASONING: James has exactly one of {Thief, Prison}, so we model that exclusive or.
FOL: ((Thief(James) & -Prison(James)) | (-Thief(James) & Prison(James))) 
TEXT: James is either with a bad record in the local state or respected by others. 
REASONING: James has exactly one of {BadRecord, Respected}, defining his status.
FOL: ((BadRecord(James) & -Respected(James)) | (-BadRecord(James) & Respected(James)))
TEXT: James contributes to the country.
REASONING: We verify whether those statuses guarantee that James contributes to the country.
FOL: ContributeToCountry(James)
</EVALUATE>

<PREMISES>
No songs are visual.
All folk songs are songs.
All videos are visual.
All movies are videos.
All sci-fi movies are movies.
Inception is a sci-fi movie.
Mac is neither a folk song nor a sci-fi movie.
</PREMISES>
<CONCLUSION>
Inception is a folk song.
</CONCLUSION>
<EVALUATE>
TEXT: No songs are visual. 
REASONING: Songs cannot be visual, so we universally quantify Song(x) → ¬Visual(x).
FOL: all x. (Song(x) -> -Visual(x))
TEXT: All folk songs are songs. 
REASONING: Folk songs are a subset of songs, capturing FolkSong(x) → Song(x).
FOL: all x. (FolkSong(x) -> Song(x))
TEXT: All videos are visual. 
REASONING: Videos are inherently visual, so Video(x) → Visual(x).
FOL: all x. (Video(x) -> Visual(x))
TEXT: All movies are videos.
REASONING: Movies are a subclass of videos, linking Movie(x) → Video(x).
FOL: all x. (Movie(x) -> Video(x))
TEXT: All sci-fi movies are movies.
REASONING: Sci-fi movies are movies, giving ScifiMovie(x) → Movie(x).
FOL: all x. (ScifiMovie(x) -> Movie(x))
TEXT: Inception is a sci-fi movie.
REASONING: We assert the specific instance Inception is a sci-fi movie.
FOL: ScifiMovie(Inception)
TEXT: Mac is neither a folk song nor a sci-fi movie.
REASONING: Mac is neither a folk song nor a sci-fi movie, ruling out both classes.
FOL: -FolkSong(Mac) & -ScifiMovie(Mac)
TEXT: Inception is a folk song.
REASONING: We then test the (false) claim that Inception is a folk song under these constraints.
FOL: FolkSong(Inception)
</EVALUATE>

<PREMISES>
Every chef can cook.
Some people who aren’t chefs can cook.
People who cook can make scrambled eggs and pasta.
If someone can make cookies and muffins, they are a baker.
Bakers who can also make scrambled eggs can make a good breakfast.
Luke can make cookies, scrambled eggs, and muffins, but not pasta.
</PREMISES>
<CONCLUSION>
Luke can make a good breakfast.
</CONCLUSION>
<EVALUATE>
TEXT: Every chef can cook.
REASONING: We use a universal quantifier (“all x”) to capture “every chef,” and the implication “Chef(x) → Cook(x)” asserts that being a chef entails the ability to cook.
FOL: all x. (Chef(x) -> Cook(x))
TEXT: Some people who aren’t chefs can cook.
REASONING: An existential quantifier (“exists x”) models “some people,” and the conjunction “¬Chef(x) & Cook(x)” picks out those non-chefs who nonetheless can cook.
FOL: exists x. (-Chef(x) & Cook(x))
TEXT: People who cook can make scrambled eggs and pasta.
REASONING: Universally we assert that cooking implies the ability to make both scrambled eggs and pasta, hence the nested implication into a conjunction.
FOL: all x. (Cook(x) -> (MakeScrambledEggs(x) & MakePasta(x)))
TEXT: If someone can make cookies and muffins, they are a baker.
REASONING: Again a universal rule: anyone satisfying both “MakeCookies(x)” and “MakeMuffins(x)” must be classified as a baker.
FOL: all x. (MakeCookies(x) & MakeMuffins(x) -> Baker(x))
TEXT: Bakers who can also make scrambled eggs can make a good breakfast.
REASONING: We restrict to those who are bakers and can make scrambled eggs, and assert they can make a good breakfast.
FOL: all x. ((Baker(x) & MakeScrambledEggs(x)) -> MakeGoodBreakfast(x))
TEXT: Luke can make cookies, scrambled eggs, and muffins, but not pasta.
REASONING: A ground conjunction records exactly which components Luke can (and cannot) make.
FOL: MakeCookies(Luke) & MakeScrambledEggs(Luke) & MakeMuffins(Luke) & -MakePasta(Luke)
TEXT: Luke can make a good breakfast.
REASONING: A simple atomic fact concluding that Luke meets the criteria for “good breakfast.”
FOL: MakeGoodBreakfast(Luke)
</EVALUATE>

<PREMISES>
ETS develops various standardized tests primarily in the United States for K-12 and higher education.
ETS administers international tests including the TOEFL, TOEIC, GRE and subject tests in more than 180 countries.
Many of the assessments ETS develops are associated with entry to the US tertiary and quaternary education institutions.
ETS also develops K-12 statewide assessments used for accountability testing in many states.
</PREMISES>
<CONCLUSION>
ETS develops assessments for K-12 statewide as well as entry to US tertiary and quaternary education institutions.
</CONCLUSION>
<EVALUATE>
TEXT: ETS develops various standardized tests primarily in the United States for K-12 and higher education. 
REASONING: We introduce some test x such that ETS develops it, it’s standardized, its location is the U.S., and its target is K-12 and higher education.
FOL: exists x. (Develops(Ets, x) & StandardizedTest(x) & In(x, Unitedstates) & For(x, k-OneTwoandhighereducation))
TEXT: ETS administers international tests including the TOEFL, TOEIC, GRE and subject tests in more than 180 countries.
REASONING: There exists a test x that ETS administers, which is international and one of the listed exams (TOEFL, TOEIC, GRE, or subject test).
FOL: exists x. (Administers(Ets, x) & InternationalTest(x) & (TOEFL(x) | TOEIC(x) | GRE(x) | SubjectTests(x)))
TEXT: Many of the assessments ETS develops are associated with entry to the US tertiary and quaternary education institutions. 
REASONING: Some development x by ETS is tied to entry to U.S. tertiary and quaternary education institutions.
FOL: exists x. (Develops(Ets, x) & AssociatedWith(x, Entrytouseducationinstitutions))
TEXT: ETS also develops K-12 statewide assessments used for accountability testing in many states.
REASONING: There is an assessment x that ETS develops, is statewide, and is used for accountability testing.
FOL: exists x. (Develops(Ets, x) & StateWideAssesment(x) & UsedFor(x, Accountabilitytesting))
TEXT: ETS develops assessments for K-12 statewide as well as entry to US tertiary and quaternary education institutions.
REASONING: We conjoin two existentials to capture both that ETS develops K-12 statewide assessments and those associated with entry to U.S. tertiary/quaternary institutions.
FOL: exists x. (Develops(Ets, x) & For(x, k-OneTwoandhighereducation)) & exists x. (Develops(Ets, x) & AssociatedWith(x, Entrytouseducationinstitutions))
</EVALUATE>

<PREMISES>
China is one of BRICS and its economy is emerging.
India is one of BRICS and its economy is emerging.
All people from China speak Chinese.
All people from India speak Hindi or English.
There is an Indian.
</PREMISES>
<CONCLUSION>
There is a person from BRICS speaking Hindi.
</CONCLUSION>
<EVALUATE>
TEXT: China is one of BRICS and its economy is emerging.
REASONING: A universal rule: if something is China, then it belongs to BRICS and is an emerging economy.
FOL: all x. (China(x) -> BRICS(x) & EmergingEconomy(x))
TEXT: India is one of BRICS and its economy is emerging.
REASONING: Analogous universal rule for India: India(x) → (BRICS(x) & EmergingEconomy(x)).
FOL: all x. (India(x) -> BRICS(x) & EmergingEconomy(x))
TEXT: All people from China speak Chinese.
REASONING: For any person x and country y, if x is from y and y is China, then x speaks Chinese.
FOL: all x. all y. (From(x, y) & China(y) -> Speak(x, Chinese))
TEXT: All people from India speak Hindi or English.
REASONING: Similarly, being from India forces speaking either Hindi or English.
FOL: all x. all y. (From(x, y) & India(y) -> Speak(x, Hindi) | Speak(x, English))
TEXT: There is an Indian.
REASONING: An existential quantifier picks out that there is at least one person from India.
FOL: exists x. exists y. (From(x, y) & India(y))
TEXT: There is a person from BRICS speaking Hindi.
REASONING: We assert that there exists someone who is both a member of BRICS and speaks Hindi.
FOL: exists x. (BRICS(x) & Speak(x, Hindi))
</EVALUATE>

<PREMISES>
If people perform in school talent shows often, then they attend and are very engaged with school events.
People either perform in school talent shows often or are inactive and disinterested members of their community.
If people chaperone high school dances, then they are not students who attend the school.
All people who are inactive and disinterested members of their community chaperone high school dances.
All young children and teenagers who wish to further their academic careers and educational opportunities are students who attend the school.
Bonnie either both attends and is very engaged with school events and is a student who attends the school, or she neither attends and is very engaged with school events nor is a student who attends the school.
</PREMISES>
<CONCLUSION>
Bonnie performs in school talent shows often.
</CONCLUSION>
<EVALUATE>
raw_generations:
TEXT: If people perform in school talent shows often, then they attend and are very engaged with school events.
REASONING: Performing in school talent shows implies that the person attends and is engaged, capturing this relation.
FOL: all x. (PerformInSchoolTalentShows(x) -> Attends(x) & VeryEngaged(x))
TEXT: People either perform in school talent shows often or are inactive and disinterested members of their community.
REASONING: People must be either frequent performers or inactive, using an exclusive or.
FOL: ((PerformInSchoolTalentShows(x) & -InactiveAndDisinterested(x)) | (-PerformInSchoolTalentShows(x) & InactiveAndDisinterested(x)))
TEXT: If people chaperone high school dances, then they are not students who attend the school.
REASONING: Chaperoning dances rules out being a student who attends the school, so we assert the implication.
FOL: all x. (ChaperoneHighSchoolDances(x) -> -StudentWhoAttends(x))
TEXT: All people who are inactive and disinterested members of their community chaperone high school dances.
REASONING: We state that inactivity disinterest guarantees chaperoning, capturing the class of inactive, disinterested individuals.
FOL: all x. (InactiveAndDisinterested(x) -> ChaperoneHighSchoolDances(x))
TEXT: All young children and teenagers who wish to further their academic careers and educational opportunities are students who attend the school.
REASONING: Young individuals who wish to further their education are students, capturing their educational goals.
FOL: all x. (WishFurtherAcademicCareers(x) -> StudentWhoAttends(x))
TEXT: Bonnie either both attends and is very engaged with school events and is a student who attends the school, or she neither attends and is very engaged with school events nor is a student who attends the school.
REASONING: We express the exclusive or concerning Bonnie’s engagement and student status.
FOL: ((Attends(x) & VeryEngaged(x) & StudentWhoAttends(x)) | (-Attends(x) & -VeryEngaged(x) & -StudentWhoAttends(x)))
TEXT: Bonnie performs in school talent shows often.
REASONING: We assert that Bonnie is a performer.
FOL: PerformInSchoolTalentShows(Bonnie)
TEXT: If people perform in school talent shows often, then they attend and are very engaged with school events.
REASONING: For any person x, if x performs in school talent shows often, then x attends and is engaged with school events.
FOL: all x. (PerformsInSchoolTalentShowsOften(x) -> AttendsAndIsVeryEngaged(x))
TEXT: People either perform in school talent shows often or are inactive and disinterested members of their community.
REASONING: People are in exactly one of those categories, so a conjunction of the negations of the disjuncts captures this exclusive or.
FOL: (-PerformsInSchoolTalentShowsOften(x) & -InactiveAndDisinterested(x)) | (-InactiveAndDisinterested(x) & -PerformsInSchoolTalentShowsOften(x))
TEXT: If people chaperone high school dances, then they are not students who attend the school.
REASONING: A universal rule: chaperoning dances entails not attending the school.
FOL: all x. (ChaperonesHighSchoolDances(x) -> -Student(x))
TEXT: All people who are inactive and disinterested members of their community chaperone high school dances.
REASONING: We assert that being inactive and disinterested forces chaperoning dances.
FOL: all x. (InactiveAndDisinterested(x) -> ChaperonesHighSchoolDances(x))
TEXT: All young children and teenagers who wish to further their academic careers and educational opportunities are students who attend the school.
REASONING: We capture that students who wish to further their education are students at the school.
FOL: all x. (WishesToFurtherAcademicCareersAndEducationalOpportunities(x) -> Student(x))
TEXT: Bonnie either both attends and is very engaged with school events and is a student who attends the school, or she neither attends and is very engaged with school events nor is a student who attends the school.
REASONING: Bonnie falls into exactly one of those categories, so we model this exclusive or with a conjunction of the negations of the disjuncts.
FOL: ((AttendsAndIsVeryEngaged(Bonnie) & Student(Bonnie)) & -AttendsAndIsVeryEngaged(Bonnie) & -Student(Bonnie))
TEXT: Bonnie performs in school talent shows often.
REASONING: We verify the implication that if Bonnie satisfies the second disjunct, she must perform in school talent shows often.
FOL: -AttendsAndIsVeryEngaged(Bonnie) & -Student(Bonnie) -> PerformsInSchoolTalentShowsOften(Bonnie)
TEXT: If people perform in school talent shows often, then they attend and are very engaged with school events. 
REASONING: People who are frequent performers are also active participants in school events, as a material implication: (PerformsInSchoolTalentShow(x) → AttendsAndIsEngaged(x)).
FOL: all x. (PerformsInSchoolTalentShow(x) -> AttendsAndIsEngaged(x))
TEXT: People either perform in school talent shows often or are inactive and disinterested members of their community. 
REASONING: We model the option: either active (performing) or inactive (disinterested), with exclusive or.
FOL: ((PerformsInSchoolTalentShow(x) & -InactiveAndDisinterested(x)) | (-PerformsInSchoolTalentShow(x) & InactiveAndDisinterested(x)))
TEXT: If people chaperone high school dances, then they are not students who attend the school. 
REASONING: Those who chaperone are not students, so we have the implication: (ChaperoneHighSchoolDances(x) → -StudentWhoAttendsSchool(x)).
FOL: all x. (ChaperoneHighSchoolDances(x) -> -StudentWhoAttendsSchool(x))
TEXT: All people who are inactive and disinterested members of their community chaperone high school dances. 
REASONING: Inactive and disinterested people are chaperones, making the implication: (InactiveAndDisinterested(x) → ChaperoneHighSchoolDances(x)).
FOL: all x. (InactiveAndDisinterested(x) -> ChaperoneHighSchoolDances(x))
TEXT: All young children and teenagers who wish to further their academic careers and educational opportunities are students who attend the school. 
REASONING: We introduce an existential quantifier, letting x be a young child or teenager who wants to further their academic careers, so they are a student who attends the school.
FOL: exists x. (YoungChildOrTeenager(x) & WantsToFurtherAcademicCareers(x) & StudentWhoAttendsSchool(x))
TEXT: Bonnie either both attends and is very engaged with school events and is a student who attends the school, or she neither attends and is very engaged with school events nor is a student who attends the school. 
REASONING: We use an exclusive or to model that Bonnie has one and only one of the two options: either she attends and is engaged or neither attends nor is engaged.
FOL: ((AttendsAndIsEngaged(Bonnie) & StudentWhoAttendsSchool(Bonnie)) | (-AttendsAndIsEngaged(Bonnie) & -StudentWhoAttendsSchool(Bonnie)))
TEXT: Bonnie performs in school talent shows often.
REASONING: We then test whether Bonnie is a frequent performer, which would make her attend and be engaged with school events.
FOL: PerformsInSchoolTalentShow(Bonnie)
TEXT: If people perform in school talent shows often, then they attend and are very engaged with school events.
REASONING: We model the implication that frequent performance in school talent shows implies attendance and engagement at school events.
FOL: all x. (PerformInSchoolTalentShows(x) -> AttendAndEngaged(x))
TEXT: People either perform in school talent shows often or are inactive and disinterested members of their community.
REASONING: People are in exactly one of two categories: frequent school talent show participants or inactive community members.
FOL: ((PerformInSchoolTalentShows(x) & -InactiveAndDisinterested(x)) | (-PerformInSchoolTalentShows(x) & InactiveAndDisinterested(x)))
TEXT: If people chaperone high school dances, then they are not students who attend the school.
REASONING: Chaperoning dances implies not being a student at the school.
FOL: all x. (ChaperoneHighSchoolDances(x) -> -Student(x))
TEXT: All people who are inactive and disinterested members of their community chaperone high school dances.
REASONING: People in the inactive and disinterested category are chaperones of high school dances.
FOL: all x. (InactiveAndDisinterested(x) -> ChaperoneHighSchoolDances(x))
TEXT: All young children and teenagers who wish to further their academic careers and educational opportunities are students who attend the school.
REASONING: Young learners with ambitions are students at the school.
FOL: all x. (WishToFurtherAcademicCareersAndEducationalOpportunities(x) -> Student(x))
TEXT: Bonnie either both attends and is very engaged with school events and is a student who attends the school, or she neither attends and is very engaged with school events nor is a student who attends the school.
REASONING: We model the biconditional that Bonnie is either in one category or the other.
FOL: (AttendAndEngaged(x) & Student(x) | (-AttendAndEngaged(x) & -Student(x)))
TEXT: Bonnie performs in school talent shows often.
REASONING: We test the conclusion that Bonnie is a frequent performer in school talent shows.
FOL: PerformInSchoolTalentShows(Bonnie)
TEXT: If people perform in school talent shows often, then they attend and are very engaged with school events.
REASONING: If people perform in school talent shows often, then they attend and are very engaged with school events.
FOL: (OftenPerformInSchoolTalentShow(x) -> AttendsAndIsVeryEngaged(x))
TEXT: People either perform in school talent shows often or are inactive and disinterested members of their community.
REASONING: For every person, either they perform in school talent shows often or they are inactive and disinterested members of their community.
FOL: all x. (OftenPerformInSchoolTalentShow(x) | InactiveAndDisinterested(x))
TEXT: If people chaperone high school dances, then they are not students who attend the school.
REASONING: The negation of being a student who attends the school is implied by chaperoning high school dances.
FOL: all x. (ChaperoneHighSchoolDances(x) -> -StudentWhoAttendsTheSchool(x))
TEXT: All people who are inactive and disinterested members of their community chaperone high school dances.
